e1.0.text: Since we’re opening already collected evidence, you just need to fill out the continuity section. Penmanship counts, no duck scratches.

e1.1.text: Oh, and for the description be specific, details matter. If you just write SD card our audit team will personally hunt you down. It’s not just bureaucracy it’s our legal shield.

e1.2.text: And make sure you sign it. That signature binds you to this item until you log it back in, no dropping it in your bag, no taking it home ‘just to check it real quick’. Chain of custody is your legal lifeline.

e2.0.text: Wonderful. Now, glove up. Seriously, no greasy fingerprints on the evidence. We don’t need your DNA on a future Netflix documentary.

e2.1.text: And carefully cut open the bottom of the bag.

e3.0.text: Smooth. Now remember, no direct access. We’ll create a bit-for-bit forensic image using a write blocker, verifying the hash integrity before and after, and then analyse.

e3.1.text: Oh, and pro tip? These little guys are easy to lose. So, document where it is where it’s going, and don’t put it anywhere you wouldn’t put a live grenade.

e3.2.text: Now let’s head back to the desk and see if this card contains a secret database…

e3.3.text: Or just 200 blurry selfies of the suspects dog.

e4.0.text: Now comes the fun part: Forensic imagining. This is where we create a bit-for-bit copy of the card, preserving every file, fragment, and every bad decision the suspect ever made on it

e4.1.text: Firstly, by using a write blocker.

e4.2.text: Write blockers are like a bouncer at the club. They let us read what’s inside. But don’t let anything, or anyone, write back. No modification, no accidental changes, no Windows deciding it needs to ‘fix’ the filesystem.

e4.3.text: First the SD card goes into the write blocker. The data is then fed to our imaging software.

e4.4.text: So lets start up the PC, we'll fire up FTK Imager and create a forensic image.

e4.5.text: And don't worry, I'll walk you through every step.

e5.0.text: Click on file and select ‘Create Image’. Since we have the physical item, we will be selecting physical drive.

e5.1.text: Now let’s choose the correct target. If you image the wrong drive, say like your own workstation, I will laugh, but also cry.

e5.2.text: We’re going for ‘dd’, we want an exact bit-for-bit copy without the added fluff embedded.

e5.3.text: Now let's give it a case number, evidence number and description. Remember this should match anything that you wrote on the bag earlier.

e5.5.text: And while we do that, lets talk hashes. Not the breakfast kind sadly. Cryptographic hashes.

e5.6.text: They’re like digital fingerprints. Before and after we image the card, we calculate a hash, typically MD5 and SHA1.

e5.7.text: Now the software has already automatically generated them for us.

e5.8.text: But its important to use another tool to double check. Don’t trust the software blindly.

e5.9.text: Even digital tools can lie, especially on a Monday. So, lets run the command line tool.
